data.title: [C++] Implement support for using Atomic through CMake `add_subdirectory()`
data.body: Closed via https://github.com/AtomicGameEngine/AtomicGameEngine/pull/1172

data.title: [C++] Support for using Atomic from source in external projects  ( CMake `add_subdirectory()` )
data.body:
`CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR` variable replaced with `ATOMIC_SOURCE_DIR` (which is alias to `Atomic_SOURCE_DIR` provided by cmake). `ATOMIC_SOURCE_DIR` points to root directory of Atomic project just like `CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR` does.

Introduced three internal cache variables that provide information to c++ projects that use engine through `add_subdirectory()`:
  * ATOMIC_INCLUDE_DIRS - list of Atomic include directories.
  * ATOMIC_DEFINITIONS - list of Atomic build definitions.
  * ATOMIC_LINK_LIBRARIES - list of Atomic link libraries.

Introduced three macros:
  * include_directories_exported() - behaves like `include_directories()`, also appends included directories to `ATOMIC_INCLUDE_DIRS` cache variable.
  * add_definitions_exported() - behaves like `add_definitions()`, also appends added definitions to `ATOMIC_DEFINITIONS` cache variable.
  * add_link_libraries_exported() - appends libraries to `ATOMIC_LINK_LIBRARIES` cache variable. Targets still have to manually link to libraries specified in `ATOMIC_LINK_LIBRARIES` variable.

Macros are to be used when includes/definitions/libraries should be exposed to game projects linking to engine.


Sample CMakeLists.txt of project that embeds engine through `add_subdirectory()`:

    cmake_minimum_required(VERSION 3.6)
    project(AtomicTest)
    
    add_subdirectory(AtomicGameEngine)
    include_directories(${ATOMIC_INCLUDE_DIRS})
    add_definitions(${ATOMIC_DEFINITIONS})
    
    set(CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS "${CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS} -std=c++11")
    
    set(SOURCE_FILES main.cpp)
    add_executable(AtomicTest ${SOURCE_FILES})
    target_link_libraries (AtomicTest ${ATOMIC_LINK_LIBRARIES})


P.S. Turns out i slipped in silencing `find_package()` warnings because they were annoying to me. I think these changes are worth having because some of packages are mutually exclusive and project would generate projects no matter configuration. If you think these changes have no place in this PR then let me know and i will fix this commit.

data.title: [Editor] Closing a scene that is not the currently focused one causes further scene changes to not appear in the scene Hierarchy view
data.body:
Yeah, that's a confusing description, I don't know how else to put it :) To repro:

-Open the Roboman3 JS example
-Create a new scene called Test2.scene, save it and close it
-Open Test.scene (the normal example scene)
-Open Test2.scene (the newly added one)
*Note that Test2.scene is now open in the scene view, with an extra tab above the scene view for Test.scene
-WITHOUT switching to Test1.scene, close it by clicking the X next to its name
-Drag a prefab into the scene view
*Note that while the object appears in the scene view, the Scene Hierarchy view does NOT include the new object

data.title: Adding UIOffscreenView
data.body:
I need UI as part of the 3D scene. This allows Turbo Badger to render additional root widgets to offscreen render targets.

Input mapping is also included, and must be opted-in, and can be disabled and re-enabled at will.

data.title: improve dark skin checkbox
data.body: This improves the the outline coverage of the image, and smooths the check outline, as mush as possile with so few pixels. From #1153

data.title: Consistent AtomicNET.dll referencing regardless of build
data.body:
This PR introduces an AtomicNET/Lib folder to C# projects which contains the AtomicNET native and managed libraries, including desktop and mobile.  This facilitates a consistent assembly referencing between custom external solutions and generated ones.  It also is a consistent assembly reference for both projects opened by a development build of the editor, as well as a redistributable one.

It also cleans up absolute paths being used in csproj, which should make solutions portable across machines.  *Note**: There may still be some cases of absolute paths to flag, I did not test moving the solution across machines.

This is a pretty core change, Windows, OSX, Android, iOS, have been tested.  Linux should also work once past CI. 

One issue introduced by the change to binary references + dependencies instead of project references where they were possible, is that source navigation between the dependent and the project no longer works and instead, since it is now a binary reference, navigation brings you to the binary assembly explorer and not the source.   It is still however possible to trace and setup breakpoints in the development build AtomicNET sources.

The external solution test was changed to reference the AtomicNET binary and works both when AtomicNET is available (with debugging) in a development build and when opened from a binary editor installation.  AtomicTool is also able to build the external solution project.

Closes #1142

data.title: [C#] - Look into Visual Studio project loading path warning
data.body:
Visual Studio warns when loading shared project files which are relative

```
The file '..\..\..\..\Script\AtomicNET\AtomicNET\Scene\InspectorAttribute.cs' 
could not be added to the project.  
'..\..\..\..\Script\AtomicNET\AtomicNET\Scene\InspectorAttribute.cs' 
is not an absolute path. - AtomicNET.Desktop			
```

data.title: [C#] - Fix malformed xml documentaion warning in third party sources
data.body:
For example ``` SDL_CLIPBOARDUPDATE = 0x900, /**< The clipboard changed */``` has a < in the comment block, which causes XML parsing to fail
' https://github.com/AtomicGameEngine/AtomicGameEngine/blob/master/Script/AtomicNET/AtomicNET/Core/SDLEvents.cs#L126

data.title: You should be able to parent multiple nodes at the same time
data.body:
For instance, when importing a terrain, it creates a lot of nodes that fills up the hierarchy. I would like to be able to create a parent node that contains all these nodes, so that they don't take up as much space. But apparently, you can't really parent multiple nodes at the same time - I try to demonstrate the issue in this screencast: (click the picture)

[![Screencast](https://s16.postimg.org/3wg69geut/heightmaps_terrain_Options1.png)](https://atomicwiki.us/videos/video.html)

data.title: [C#] - Split out common Release/Debug properties to a Common method
data.body:
The NET solution generator is suffering from some copy and paste between Release/Debug property group setup, split common ones out to a method, also many of them could be passed a flag whether debug or release so combined as well

https://github.com/AtomicGameEngine/AtomicGameEngine/blob/master/Source/ToolCore/NETTools/NETProjectGen.cpp#L393

data.title: Fixes #177 - Display name of JS file in inspector when a JS component is selected
data.body:
I opted for just displaying the bare .js filename with the .js file extension here.  

So,
```Components/Spinner.js``` would be titled ```Spinner.js```.  That should give enough information to know that it is a JSComponent and that it resides in Spinner.js and doesn't take up extra screen real-estate on the title bar.

I didn't touch the way the C# components display (the class name).

data.title: Adding a CSComponent doesn't give the option to select which CS class to use

milestone.title: Issue Staging
milestone.description: A staging area for milestones, while we work through the backlog

data.body:
I tried adding a new Logic->CSComponent in the latest master branch.  The inspector shows a CSComponent attribute block, but there is no dropdown or ellipses there to select which C# class to use.  

The .dll file did get generated when I loaded up the project. (testing with the 2D C# example)

data.title: Updating README.md
[Windows] - Add support for building Atomic with D3D11/OpenGL as options
data.body: Currently Atomic builds using D3D9 on Windows, we should include ```--opengl``` and ```--d3d11``` options for Build_AtomicEditor

A number of small issue fixes
[Editor] Synchronize with player
data.body: It would be very helpful to be able to view and manipulate a scene in the editor corresponding to the player's currently running scene, with a separately controlled camera, ability to select objects and view their components, etc. Similar to Unity's Scene View of the running game.

data.title: Adding Tools -> Logs folder for opening log file location, making tools folder available when no project loaded
data.body:
This PR adds a logs subitem to the Tools menu which opens the folder containing the editor or player log files

data.title: [Windows, Editor] - Make windows/console subsystem configurable for builds
data.body: By default, release builds use the Windows subsystem which hides the attached console window, make this configurable between console/windows for builds

data.title: [Editor] - Scene hierarchy drag and drop ListView issues
data.body: There are issues with drag and drop on the hierarchy list view, sometimes operations don't work at all, or are flakey.
